Real Analysis, October 1977

  1. Prove that the sequence

2,22,222,…\sqrt{2}, \quad \sqrt{2 \sqrt{2}}, \quad \sqrt{2 \sqrt{2 \sqrt{2}}}, \ldots

converges and find its limit.
2. For which real- xx does

limn→∞xn1+x2n\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{x^{n}}{1+x^{2 n}}

converge? On which real sets is the convergence uniform?
3 . (i) Give, if possible, an example of a function on [0,∞)[0, \infty) whose improper Riemann integral exists and is finite, but which is not in L1(0,∞)L^{1}(0, \infty) (Lebesgue measure).
(ii) Give, if possible, an example of a sequence of Lebesgue integrable functions converging everywhere to a Lebesgue integrable function ff, with

limn+∞∫−∞∞fn(x)dx>∫−∞∞f(x)dx\lim _{n+\infty} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f_{n}(x) d x>\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(x) d x

(iii) Give, if possible, an example of a Riemann integrable function on (0,1](0,1] whose points of discontinuity are dense.
4. For an interval I=(a,β]≤(0,1]I=(a, \beta] \leq(0,1], let XI(x)=1X_{I}(x)=1 if x∈Ix \in I and 0 otherwise. For any simple function f(x)=∑ajXIj(x)f(x)=\sum a_{j} X_{I_{j}}(x), where {Ij=(aj,βj]}\left\{I_{j}=\left(a_{j}, \beta_{j}\right]\right\} is a finite disjoint collection of intervals define

ℓ(f)=Σaj(βj34−aj34)\ell(f)=\Sigma a_{j}\left(\beta_{j}^{\frac{3}{4}}-a_{j}^{\frac{3}{4}}\right)

Prove

|ℓ(f)|2≤2∫01|f(x)|2dx|\ell(f)|^{2} \leq 2 \int_{0}^{1}|f(x)|^{2} d x

for all ff in L2(0,1)L^{2}(0,1).
5. State the Hahn and Jordan decomposition theorems for signed (real) measures. (Do not prove them.) Illustrate the theorems by considering the measure

μ(Δ)=∫Δsin⁡tdt\mu(\Delta)=\int_{\Delta} \sin t d t

where Δ\Delta is a Borel subset of [−1,1][-1,1].
6. Prove that if a continuous linear functional ℓ\ell on C[−1,1]C[-1,1] satisfies

ℓ(1)=1ℓ(fn)=0, where fn(x)=xn\begin{aligned} \ell(1) & =1 \\ \ell\left(f_{n}\right) & =0, \text { where } f_{n}(x)=x^{n} \end{aligned}

n=1,2,…n=1,2, \ldots, then

ℓ(f)=f(0) for each f in C[−1,1].\ell(f)=f(0) \text { for each } f \text { in } C[-1,1] .

HINT: Weierstrass approximation theorem.
7. Prove that

limn→∞∫−∞∞f(t)sin⁡ntdt=0\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(t) \sin n t d t=0

if (i) f(t)=X(a,b)(t)f(t)=X_{(a, b)}(t), where −∞<a<b<∞-\infty<a<b<\infty. Then deduce that (ii) (*) holds if f∈L1(−∞,∞)f \in L^{1}(-\infty, \infty).

Real Analysis, April 1978

  1. Show that the series

∑k=1∞ln⁡(1+kx)kxk\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{\ln (1+k x)}{k x^{k}}

converges uniformly on [a,∞)[a, \infty) for every a>1a>1.
2. If r>1r>1, for what values of p,1≤p≤∞p, 1 \leq p \leq \infty does x−1/r(1+|ℓnx|)−1x^{-1 / r}(1+|\ell n x|)^{-1} belong to Lp(0,∞)L_{p}(0, \infty) ?
3. If λ\lambda and μ\mu are σ\sigma-finite measures on ( X,ℬX, \mathcal{B} ) with λ≪μ\lambda \ll \mu and gg denotes the Radon-Nikodym derivative of λ\lambda with respect to μ\mu, prove that for every non-negative measurable function ff,

∫Xfdλ=∫Xfgdμ\int_{X} f d \lambda=\int_{X} f g d \mu

  1. Let ff be a real-valued function on [0,1][0,1]. Define the set CC by

C={x∈[0,1]:f is continuous at x}.C=\{x \in[0,1]: f \text { is continuous at } x\} .

Is CC measurable? Justify your answer.
5. If f∈L1(0,1)f \in L^{1}(0,1) and ∫0xf(t)dt=x\int_{0}^{x} f(t) d t=x for every x∈(0,1)x \in(0,1) prove that f(x)=1f(x)=1 a.e. on (0,1)(0,1).
6. Let MM be a closed linear subspace of L1(0,1)L^{1}(0,1) and f∈L1(0,1)f \in L^{1}(0,1) with f∉Mf \notin M. Show that there exists a g∈L∞(0,1)g \in L^{\infty}(0,1) such that

∫01f(t)g(t)dt=1\int_{0}^{1} f(t) g(t) d t=1

and

∫01u(t)g(t)dt=0, all u∈M\int_{0}^{1} u(t) g(t) d t=0, \quad \text { all } u \in M

  1. Let {fn}\left\{f_{n}\right\} be a sequence of measurable real-valued functions on the real ℝ\mathbb{R} such that

∑n=1∞∫−∞+∞|fn(x)|dx<∞\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty}\left|f_{n}(x)\right| d x<\infty

Prove that the series ∑n=1∞fn(x)\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} f_{n}(x) converges for almost all x∈ℝx \in \mathbb{R} and that for every Borel set EE

∫E(∑n=1∞fn(x))dx=∑n=1∞(∫Efn(x)dx)\int_{E}\left(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} f_{n}(x)\right) d x=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\left(\int_{E} f_{n}(x) d x\right)

  1. Let ( X,ℬ,μX, \mathcal{B}, \mu ) be a σ\sigma-finite measure space, g∈L1(X)g \in L^{1}(X), and 𝒜\mathcal{A} a σ\sigma-algebra with 𝒜⊆ℬ\mathcal{A} \subseteq \mathcal{B}. Prove that there exists an 𝒜\mathcal{A}-measurable function defined a.e. on XX such that for every A∈𝒜A \in \mathcal{A}.

∫Afdμ=∫Agdμ\int_{A} f d \mu=\int_{A} g d \mu

Show that if f′f^{\prime} is any other 𝒜\mathcal{A}-measurable function satisfying (*)(*), then f′=ff^{\prime}=f a.e.

Real Analysis, September 1978

  1. (a) State the Mean Value Theorem.
    (b) Let f(x)f(x) be differentiable for x>0x>0. Prove that if

limx→∞f′(x)=0\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} f^{\prime}(x)=0

then

limx→∞[f(x+1)−f(x)]=0\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty}[f(x+1)-f(x)]=0

  1. Let fn(x)f_{n}(x) be a sequence of increasing functions on 0≤x≤10 \leq x \leq 1 which converges pointwise to a function f(x)f(x). Prove that if f(x)f(x) is continuous, then fn(x)f_{n}(x) converges uniformly to f(x)f(x).

  2. For α>0\alpha>0 and β>0\beta>0, let

f(x){xαsin⁡(1xβ)x≠00x=0f(x) \begin{cases}x^{\alpha} \sin \left(\frac{1}{x^{\beta}}\right) & x \neq 0 \\ 0 & x=0\end{cases}

(a) For what values of α\alpha and β\beta is f(x)f(x) continuous?
(b) For what values of α\alpha and β\beta is f(x)f(x) of bounded variation on −1≤x≤1-1 \leq x \leq 1 ?
4. Assume that f(x)∈Lp[0,∞)f(x) \in L_{p}[0, \infty) for some p,1≤p<∞p, 1 \leq p<\infty, and that f(x)f(x) is uniformly continuous on [0,∞)[0, \infty). Prove that

limx→∞f(x)=0\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} f(x)=0

  1. Let K(x,y)K(x, y) be a measurable function on the square 0≤x,y≤10 \leq x, y \leq 1 satisfying

∫01∫01|K(x,y)|2dxdy<∞\int_{0}^{1} \int_{0}^{1}|K(x, y)|^{2} d x d y<\infty

Prove that if f∈L2[0,1]f \in L_{2}[0,1], then the integral

g(x)=∫01K(x,y)f(y)dyg(x)=\int_{0}^{1} K(x, y) f(y) d y

converges for a.e. xx and that g∈L2[0,1]g \in L_{2}[0,1].
6. Let μ\mu and ν\nu be finite Borel measures on [0,∞][0, \infty].
(a) Prove that there is a unique finite Borel measure on [0,∞)[0, \infty) such that for every bounded continuous function ϕ(x)\phi(x),

∫0∞ϕ(x)dλ(x)=∫0∞∫0∞ϕ(xy)dμ(x)dν(x)\int_{0}^{\infty} \phi(x) d \lambda(x)=\int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{\infty} \phi(x y) d \mu(x) d \nu(x)

(b) If dμ(x)=h(x)dxd \mu(x)=h(x) d x is absolutely continuous (with respect to Lebesgue measure), prove that λ\lambda is also absolutely continuous, and compute its Radon-Nikodym derivative.
7. State Egorov’s Theorem. Give a counter-example on an infinite measure space.
8. (a) Suppose f,g∈L1(−∞,∞)f, g \in L_{1}(-\infty, \infty). Prove that

h(x)=∫−∞∞f(x+t)g(t)dth(x)=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(x+t) g(t) d t

exists for almost all real xx and defines a function in L1(−∞,∞)L_{1}(-\infty, \infty).
(b) Suppose g∈L1(−1,1)g \in L_{1}(-1,1) and

∫−11xng(x)dx=0 for n=0,1,…\int_{-1}^{1} x^{n} g(x) d x=0 \text { for } n=0,1, \ldots

Prove g=0g=0 a.e.

Real Analysis, January 1979

  1. Find the maximum of the expression

x−y2+z3x4+y4+z4\frac{x-\frac{y}{2}+\frac{z}{3}}{x^{4}+y^{4}+z^{4}}

over the region x4+y4+z4≥1x^{4}+y^{4}+z^{4} \geq 1.
2. Let f(x)f(x) be a function of bounded variation on (−∞,∞)(-\infty, \infty). Suppose that F(x)F(x) has compact support and that each continuously differential function f(x)f(x) satisfies

∫−∞∞F(x)f′(x)dx=0\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} F(x) f^{\prime}(x) d x=0

Show that F(x)=0F(x)=0.
3. Suppose that {fn(x)}\left\{f_{n}(x)\right\} is a sequence of measurable functions on [0,1][0,1] for which

f(x)=limn→∞fn(x) exists a.e. f(x)=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} f_{n}(x) \text { exists a.e. }

Suppose that

limn→∞∫01|fn(x)−f(x)|dx=0\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \int_{0}^{1}\left|f_{n}(x)-f(x)\right| d x=0

and that

supn∫01|fn(x)|2dx<∞\sup _{n} \int_{0}^{1}\left|f_{n}(x)\right|^{2} d x<\infty

Show that ∫01|f(x)|2dx<∞\int_{0}^{1}|f(x)|^{2} d x<\infty. Does it follow that lim⁡n→∞∫01|fn(x)−f(x)|2dx\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \int_{0}^{1}\left|f_{n}(x)-f(x)\right|^{2} d x. (Prove or give a counter-example.)
4. Let f(x)f(x) be measurable on (−∞,+∞)(-\infty,+\infty) and satisfy

∫−∞∞|f(x)|2dx<∞\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}|f(x)|^{2} d x<\infty

Show that for each hh the integral

∫−∞∞f(x)f(x+h)dx\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(x) f(x+h) d x

converges absolutely. Define

g(h)≡∫−∞∞f(x)f(x+h)dxg(h) \equiv \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(x) f(x+h) d x

and show that g(h)g(h) is continuous and that

lim|h|→∞g(h)=0.\lim _{|h| \rightarrow \infty} g(h)=0 .

  1. Let f(λ,x)f(\lambda, x) be a continuous function of two variables, 0<λ<10<\lambda<1 and 0<x<10<x<1. Suppose that ∂f∂λ(λ,x)\frac{\partial f}{\partial \lambda}(\lambda, x) exists for all λ\lambda and xx and that

h(x)=sup0<λ<1|∂f∂λ(λ,x)|h(x)=\sup _{0<\lambda<1}\left|\frac{\partial f}{\partial \lambda}(\lambda, x)\right|

satisfies ∫01h(x)dx<∞\int_{0}^{1} h(x) d x<\infty.
Show that the function F(λ)≡∫01f(λ,x)dxF(\lambda) \equiv \int_{0}^{1} f(\lambda, x) d x is differentiable and satisfies

F′(λ)=∫01∂f∂λ(λ,x)dxF^{\prime}(\lambda)=\int_{0}^{1} \frac{\partial f}{\partial \lambda}(\lambda, x) d x

  1. Show that a convex function defined on an open interval is continuous.

  2. Does there exist a nowhere dense set of positive Lebesgue measure in [0,1][0,1] ? Prove or give an example.

Real Analysis, January 1980

  1. Let f(x)f(x) be a continuous function on [0,1][0,1] such that

∫01xnf(x)dx=0; for n=0,1,2,…\int_{0}^{1} x^{n} f(x) d x=0 ; \quad \text { for } n=0,1,2, \ldots

Either prove that f(x)≡0f(x) \equiv 0 or give a counter-example.
2. Let f(x)f(x) be an integrable function on [0,1][0,1]. Either prove or give a counter-example that

limn→∞∫01xnf(x)dx=0\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \int_{0}^{1} x^{n} f(x) d x=0

  1. Let ∑n=0∞ane−nx\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} a_{n} e^{-n x} be a series which converges at x=0x=0. Prove that the series converges uniformly on the interval [1,∞)[1, \infty).

  2. Let {fn(x)}\left\{f_{n}(x)\right\} be a sequence of continuous functions on [0,∞)[0, \infty). Show that the set EE of points xx for which {fn(x)}\left\{f_{n}(x)\right\} converges is Borel measurable.

  3. Let {ak}\left\{a_{k}\right\} be a sequence such that the series ∑k=1∞akxk\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_{k} x_{k} converges whenever ∑k=1∞|xk|2<∞\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\left|x_{k}\right|^{2}< \infty. Show that ∑k=1∞|ak|2<∞\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\left|a_{k}\right|^{2}<\infty.

  4. Prove that if an≥0(n=0,1,2,…)a_{n} \geq 0(n=0,1,2, \ldots) and if

f(t)=∑n=0∞antn≤c(0≤t<1),f(t)=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} a_{n} t^{n} \leq c \quad(0 \leq t<1),

then the function f(t)f(t) has a limit as t→1t \rightarrow 1, equal to

∑n=0∞an.\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} a_{n} .

  1. Let μ(dt)\mu(d t) and ν(dt)\nu(d t) be two finite Borel measures on the half line (0,∞)(0, \infty). Show that there is a unique finite measure ω(dx)\omega(d x) and (0,∞)(0, \infty) which satisfies

∫0∞f(z)ω(dx)=∫0∞{∫0∞f(st)μ(dt)}ν(ds)\int_{0}^{\infty} f(z) \omega(d x)=\int_{0}^{\infty}\left\{\int_{0}^{\infty} f(s t) \mu(d t)\right\} \nu(d s)

for each bounded continuous function ff on (0,∞)(0, \infty).
Find an explicit formula for ω(dx)\omega(d x).

Real Analysis, September 1980

  1. Define

g(x)={|x|αlog⁡|x| if x≠00 if x=0g(x)= \begin{cases}|x|^{\alpha} \log |x| & \text { if } x \neq 0 \\ 0 & \text { if } x=0\end{cases}

Find all α\alpha such that g′(0)g^{\prime}(0) exists.
2. True or False. (If true, give a proof; if false, give a counter-example.) If ff is a real-valued differentiable function on (0,1)(0,1), then ff is measurable on (0,1)(0,1).
3. Let f(x,t)f(x, t) be a real-valued function on ℝ2\mathbb{R}^{2} such that for all t∈ℝ,f(,t)t \in \mathbb{R}, f(\quad, t) is continuous. Suppose there exists a Lebesgue integrable function g(t)g(t) such that

|f(x,t)|≤g(t), for all x,t∈ℝ|f(x, t)| \leq g(t), \text { for all } x, t \in \mathbb{R}

Prove that the function

F(x)=∫ℝf(x,t)cos⁡tdtF(x)=\int_{\mathbb{R}} f(x, t) \cos t d t

is finite and continuous.
4. Prove that if {an,m:n=1,2,…;m=1,2,…}\left\{a_{n, m}: n=1,2, \ldots ; m=1,2, \ldots\right\} are non-negative real numbers, then

∑n=1∞∑m=1∞an,m=∑m=1∞∑m=1∞an,m\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \sum_{m=1}^{\infty} a_{n, m}=\sum_{m=1}^{\infty} \sum_{m=1}^{\infty} a_{n, m}

  1. Prove that C[0,1]C[0,1], the continuous complex functions on [0,1][0,1], with inner product ( f,gf, g ) = ∫01fgdx\int_{0}^{1} f g d x is not a Hilbert space.

  2. Let α(x)\alpha(x) be a monotone increasing function on [0,1][0,1] such that α′(x)\alpha^{\prime}(x) exists a.e. on [0,1][0,1]. Prove directly that

α(1)−α(0)≥∫01α′(x)dx\alpha(1)-\alpha(0) \geq \int_{0}^{1} \alpha^{\prime}(x) d x

Give an example to show equality does not always hold.
7. (a) Let hh be a non-negative Lebesgue integrable function on ℝ\mathbb{R}. For each measurable set E⊂ℝE \subset \mathbb{R}, define

μ(E)=∫Eh(x)dλ(x)\mu(E)=\int_{E} h(x) d \lambda(x)

where λ\lambda is Lebesgue measure.
Prove directly that if ff is a real-valued function on ℝ\mathbb{R}, then ff is integrable with respect to μ\mu if and only if fhf h is integrable with respect to λ\lambda and if ff is integrable

∫ℝfdμ=∫ℝfhdλ\int_{\mathbb{R}} f d \mu=\int_{\mathbb{R}} f h d \lambda

(b) Find the Radon-Nikodym derivative of μ\mu with respect to λ\lambda, i.e., dμdλ\frac{d \mu}{d \lambda}. Defend your selection.

Real Analysis, January 1981

  1. Definition. A real-valued function defined on an interval of ℝ1\mathbb{R}^{1} has a relative maximum at xx if there exists a neighborhood NN of xx such that f(y)≤f(x)f(y) \leq f(x) for all y∈Ny \in N. It has a proper maximum at xx if there exists a neighborhood NN of xx such that f(y)<f(x)f(y)<f(x) for all y∈Ny \in N.
    Prove that any real-valued function defined on an interval of ℝ1\mathbb{R}^{1} has only a countable number of proper maximums.
    Give an example to show that the statement is false if proper maximum is replaced by relative maximum.

  2. Let aa and cc be real numbers with c>0c>0. Define ff on [0,1][0,1] by

f(x)={xasin⁡(x−c) if x≠00 if x=0f(x)= \begin{cases}x^{a} \sin \left(x^{-c}\right) & \text { if } x \neq 0 \\ 0 & \text { if } x=0\end{cases}

Prove:
(a) ff is continuous iff a>0a>0;
(b) f′(0)f^{\prime}(0) exists iff a>1a>1;
(c) f′f^{\prime} is bounded iff a≥1+ca \geq 1+c.
3. Prove or give a counter-example: If ff is differentiable on (0,1)(0,1), then its derivative is a measurable function on (0,1)(0,1).
4. (a) Show that sin⁡x(1+x)2\frac{\sin x}{(1+x)^{2}} is Lebesgue integrable on (0,∞)(0, \infty) but cos⁡x1+x\frac{\cos x}{1+x} is not.
(b) Prove that

limA→∞∫0Acos⁡x1+xdx=∫0∞cos⁡x1+xdx\lim _{A \rightarrow \infty} \int_{0}^{A} \frac{\cos x}{1+x} d x=\int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{\cos x}{1+x} d x

exists, and

∫0∞cos⁡x1+xdx=∫(0,∞)sin⁡x(1+x)2dx\int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{\cos x}{1+x} d x=\int_{(0, \infty)} \frac{\sin x}{(1+x)^{2}} d x

  1. Let f(x,t)f(x, t) be a function defined on (0,1)×(0,1)(0,1) \times(0,1) to ℝ1\mathbb{R}^{1} such that
    (a) ∂∂tf(,t0)\frac{\partial}{\partial t} f\left(\quad, t_{0}\right) exists for all t0∈(0,1)t_{0} \in(0,1);
    (b) there exists g∈L1(0,1)g \in L^{1}(0,1) such that

|f(x,t1)−f(x,t2)|≤g(x)|t1−t2|\left|f\left(x, t_{1}\right)-f\left(x, t_{2}\right)\right| \leq g(x)\left|t_{1}-t_{2}\right|

for all x,t1,t2∈(0,1)x, t_{1}, t_{2} \in(0,1).
Prove that f(⋅,t)∈L1(0,1)f(\cdot, t) \in L^{1}(0,1) for each t∈(0,1)t \in(0,1), that ∂f∂t(⋅,t)∈L1(0,1)\frac{\partial f}{\partial t}(\cdot, t) \in L^{1}(0,1) for each t∈(0,1)t \in(0,1) and that

ddt∫01f(x,t)dx=∫01∂f∂t(x,t)dx\frac{d}{d t} \int_{0}^{1} f(x, t) d x=\int_{0}^{1} \frac{\partial f}{\partial t}(x, t) d x

  1. Assume as known that every set in ℝn\mathbb{R}^{n} of positive Lebesgue measure contains a nonmeasurable set.

Let TT be a bijection of a bounded measurable set E⊂ℝnE \subset \mathbb{R}^{n} to T(E)⊂ℝnT(E) \subset \mathbb{R}^{n} such that T(A)T(A) is measurable if and only if AA is measurable. Let μ\mu be Lebesgue measure on EE.
